newsitem.title: INDIA: India's RBI issues summary of credit policy.
newsitem.headline: India's RBI issues summary of credit policy.

text.p: The Reserve Bank of India on Tuesday issued the following summary of its monetary and credit policy Measures for the first half of 1997/98 (April-March).
RESERVE REQUIREMENTS AND REFINANCE:
CASH RESERVE RATIO:
** Exemption from maintenance of cash reserve ratio (CRR) on liabilities to Banking System.

** Imposition of CRR of 10 percent on increase in Liabilities under Foreign Currency Non-Resident (banks) deposit scheme (FCNR(B), non-repatriatable (NRNR) and non-resident external (NRE) schemes over the level as on April 11, 1997.
STATUTORY LIQUIDITY:
** Exemption from maintenance of statutory liquidity ratio on liabilities to banking system.
REFINANCE FROM RBI:

** Introduction of General Refinance Scheme under which Refinance Limits would be available upto 1 percent of average aggregate deposits during 1996/97 at Bank Rate for first four weeks and at Bank Rate plus 1 percentage point for second four weeks.
** Withdrawal of Base level Export Credit Refinance Limits (at 20 percent of Export Credit as on February 16, 1996).
INTEREST RATES:
BANK RATE:
** Reduction in Bank Rate by one percentage point from 12 percent to 11 percent per annum.
DEPOSIT RATES:

** Reduction in the ceiling on interest rate on domestic term deposits for maturity of 30 days and upto one year from 10 percent to Bank Rate minus two percentage points per annum (9.0 percent) and link deposit rate to Bank Rate.

** Interest rates on term deposits under NRE Scheme brought on par with domestic term deposits - Reduction in ceiling on interest rate by three percentage points from 12 percent to Bank Rate minus 2 percentage points per annum (9.0 percent) on maturity of 6 months and upto one year and freedom given to banks for determining their own interest rates on NRE deposits of maturity of over 1 year.
** Freedom given to banks to determine their own interest rates on deposits under FCNR(B) scheme subject to ceiling prescribed by RBI from time to time.
INTEREST RATES ON ADVANCES:
** Change in prescription of interest rate on post-shipment rupee export credit upto 90 days from 13.0 percent per annum to 'not exceeding 13.0 percent per annum'.
MONEY MARKET DEVELOPMENT:
** To further develop the money market and make it more efficient, a Standing Advisory Committee on Money Market is being set up to advise the Reserve Bank.

** Providing access to entities as lenders in the call/notice money market through primary dealers in addition to Discount and Finance House of India (DFHI) and minimum size of operation reduced from 200 million rupees to 100 million rupees.
** Reduction in minimum size of issue of CDs from 2.5 million rupees to 1.0 million rupees in multiples of 0.5 million rupees.
** The minimum maturity of CP brought down from 3 months to 30 days.
GOVERNMENT SECURITIES MARKET:
** To activate Repos market, Repo/reverse repo transactions allowed in all dated Central Government Securities besides Treasury bills of all mauturities.

** Non-bank entities who are holders of subsidiary general ledger (SGL) accounts with the RBI are allowed to enter into reverse repo transactions with banks/primary dealers in Treasury bills of all maturities and all dated central government securities allowed.
** Introduction of Treasury bills of varying maturities.
FOREIGN EXCHANGE:

** Exporters holding exchange earners foreign currency (EEFC) account are permitted to extend trade related advances to their importer clients out of EEFC accounts upto three million dollars per account.

** Authorised dealers permitted to borrow upto 10 million dollars from their foreign offices/correspondents without any conditions on end use and repayment of such borrowings and allowing authorised dealers to invest funds in overseas money market instruments upto $10 million.

** With a view to impact flexibility to corporates and improve liquidity in the financial markets, authorised dealers are permitted to book forward cover for exporters and importers on the basis of a declaration of exposure supported by past performance and business projection without the earlier requirement of documentary evidence of a firm order or letter of credit. However, total forward contracts outstanding should not exceed the average export/import turnover of the last two years.
** Authorised dealers allowed to run a swap-book and offer forex rupee currency swap between two corporates without prior approval of RBI.
IMPROVING CREDIT DELIVERY SYSTEM:
** Freedom given to banks to evolve their own methods of assessing the working capital needs of borrowers within the prudential guidelines and exposure needs.

** Banks allowed to extend loans to corporates against shares held by them to enable such corporates to meet the promoters' contribution to the equity of new companies and these loans will be treated as banks' investments in shares and would come under the ceiling of five percent.

** Complete freedom given to banks in the matter of credit dispensation without obligation on the part of banks to form a consortium even if credit limit exceeds 500 million rupees subject to observance of exposure limits. Syndication is also allowed if arrangement suits borrower and financing banks.

** Freedom given to bank boards to demarcate the activities that may not be subject to loan delivery system. Loan component raised to 80 per cent and 75 per cent, respectively, for borrowers with working capital limit of 200 million rupees and above and 100 million rupees and above respectively.

** Changes made in loan system. Minimum period of loan and spread over various maturities subject to roll over to be decided by banks. Short-term/temporary surplus of borrowers may be invested in money market instruments.

** During 1997/98 a further injection of 500 million rupees to be provided raising the capital of National Bank for Agriculture and Rural Development (NABARD) to 15 billion rupees taking Reserve Bank's contribution to 10.5 billion. The limit under General Line of Credit from RBI to NABARD raised by two billion rupees from 55 billion to 57 billion.

** Assessment of working capital needs on the basis of 20 per cent of projected turnover of village, tiny and other small scale industry units extended to borrowers having working capital limits upto 20 million rupees as against 10 million earlier. The limit on investment in the small scale industries sector is enhanced from five million rupees (7.5 million in the case of export oriented and ancillary units) raised to 30 million.

**Bank's investment in preference shares/debentures/bonds of private corporate bodies to be excluded from the limit of five percent of their incremental deposits in the previous year. Thus ceiling of five per cent will be applicable for investment in ordinary shares of corporates including PSUs.

**Freedom given to banks for determining the level of credit to (registered and certified) Non -Banking Financial Companies (NBFCs) instead of restriction of upto certain multiples of NBFCs' net own funds.
